Answer: From my experience of translating texts for publication in journals, magazines and periodicals, there has been a considerable contraction in the length of articles. Brevity seems preferable to analysis and in-depth coverage. The message has to be got across in as short a length of text as possible. Online publication is also decimating the lead-time for articles - there is a demand for "instant gratification". Online publishing taking over from print as the favoured medium has also changed the game. Deadlines for filing copy have become tighter, to the detriment of quality. Sensationalism hasFrom my experience of translating texts for publication in journals, magazines and periodicals, there has been a considerable contraction in the length of articles. Brevity seems preferable to analysis and in-depth coverage. The message has to be got across in as short a length of text as possible. Online publication is also decimating the lead-time for articles - there is a demand for "instant gratification". Online publishing taking over from print as the favoured medium has also changed the game. Deadlines for filing copy have become tighter, to the detriment of quality. Sensationalism has taken over from reporting hard and fast facts. Technological advances have also meant there is far greater freedom in terms of creativity with regard to layout - the printed word is no longer just in black and white.

Answer: IrrelevanceSpeedMore cursory journalismIrrelevanceSpeedMore cursory journalismTake any of the police murders during the last year and see the amount of completely incorrect information that's written by "journalists" and you see how the push for information now (with their accompanying clicks and revenue generation) often trumps the push for good information. Even checking resources has become an afterthought to just getting something shareable on Facebook published ASAP.DataAs technology progresses, the most successful journalists are going to be the ones that can balance good, well-researched reporting with analytical understanding of how best to present the information to maximize exposure.

Answer: I think the main change in journalism profession is REACH. With the advancement of internet, and proliferation of various social networking sites and other blogging platforms, journalists no longer need to be associated with any particular media establishment to reach masses. Nowadays any journalist can assemble an audience of hundreds and hundreds of thousands.

A wheel isn’t that impressive, technologically speaking, but when you’ve got a wheel you can transport loads farther and faster. It allowsYes,They’reTechnology doesn’t progress in a linear fashion, nor do we expect it to. Technology begets technology. A wheel isn’t that impressive, technologically speaking, but when you’ve got a wheel you can transport loads farther and faster. It allowsThe plow revolutionizes your farming techniques, which frees you to come up with evenMastering fire allows you to cook your food, which generally makes you healthier, which lets you live longer and you know…None of these things was invented in the last 150 years, I know, but I’m using them as illustrations of how one technological advancement paves the way for many, many more.And of course, as technology moves forward, there are new challenges to solve. That motivates people to create technology they weren’t even aware they would need in the past.The more technology youSo no, it isn’t suspicious at all that human technology languished in the “dark ages” for such a long time, and then reached a tipping point where it enabled people to live long, productive lives and dream up more technology. It’s precisely what you’d expect.

Answer: Stephen Jay Gould discussed this in one of his essays. He pointed out that human cultural development (including technology) happens by a kind of Lamarckian evolution, in which society itself changes to absorb new culture.When computers were developed it was possible for old codgers like me to learn to use them. It was not necessary for all of the old people to die off in order that computers could be generally used, not just by young people.The likelihood of new, popular developments in technology being invented and adopted is roughly proportional to the technological sophistication existingStephen Jay Gould discussed this in one of his essays. He pointed out that human cultural development (including technology) happens by a kind of Lamarckian evolution, in which society itself changes to absorb new culture.When computers were developed it was possible for old codgers like me to learn to use them. It was not necessary for all of the old people to die off in order that computers could be generally used, not just by young people.The likelihood of new, popular developments in technology being invented and adopted is roughly proportional to the technological sophistication existing at the time, so we get exponential growth in technology.

Answer: Imagine you were sent back in time to the stone age.Unfortunately you are stuck there until you can make a cell phone to call for help. Fortunately you are immortal, so you can take as long as you need.How long will it take you to make a cellphone?You already have the massive advantage of 1) knowing that cellphones are possible, 2) having a vague idea of the technologies involved.But consider that there are 118 known elements. (eg. Hydrogen, Helium, Lithium etc…) and the typical cell phone uses 75 of those elements.You have to figure out:Imagine you were sent back in time to the stone age.Unfortunately you are stuck there until you can make a cell phone to call for help. Fortunately you are immortal, so you can take as long as you need.How long will it take you to make a cellphone?You already have the massive advantage of 1) knowing that cellphones are possible, 2) having a vague idea of the technologies involved.But consider that there are 118 known elements. (eg. Hydrogen, Helium, Lithium etc…) and the typical cell phone uses 75 of those elements.You have to figure out:Of all those, you probably only really know the last one. (#8)What else you know depends on your profession.If you are a Geologist, you might know what some elements look like in nature.If you are a Miner, you might know how to extract some of them from the earth.If you are a Refining Plant Manager you might know how to refine some of them.If you are a Materials Scientist or Metallurgist you might know how to combine some of them into polymers or alloys.If you are an Engineer you might know how to design parts of a cellphone, but probably only some of the parts.If you are a Mechanist or Factory Worker you might know how to build some of the parts.If you are a Software Engineer you might know how to program some of the electronics.What we are getting at is that there is no such thing as a “Cellphone Maker”.But it gets worse.While the professions listed above know aspects of how to make a cellphone, they also rely on other technology in order to do their jobs.For the Geologist, lets say he really knows his rocks and doesn’t need any fancy electronic testing equipment, which is a good thing, because such equipment is just as complex as a cellphone.But he needs the Miner to dig and get at rocks and oil underground before he can identify them. For this, theSo before we can start making a cell phone, we’re going to need to make an steel pickaxe.How to make an Steel Pickaxe:Oops. We don’t have a pickaxe yet, that’s what we’re trying to make. Now what? How else can we make a pickaxe?How to make a Stone Pickaxe:Oops. We don’t have any rope. Or leather cord. Or anything else to tie with.How to make a Leather Cord:Oops. We need leather first. Where are we going to get leather?How to make Leather:Oops. We don’t have any cows because they haven’t been domesticated yet. We’ll have to make our leather out of something else, such as a deer.How to kill a Deer:Really? A bow and arrow? How do we make that? Better just look for a dead deer lying around somewhere. Oh look there’s one over there. Perfect.How to make Leather From a Deer (Round 2):Just kidding. Don’t have a knife.How to make Leather From a Deer (Round 3):Where do we get salt? Ok the ocean has salt. Easy.How to get Salt from the Ocean:Oh no. How do we make a bucket?How to make a Leather Bucket:Nope. Don’t even start.How to make a Reed Bucket:Ok, we can do that. Finally, progress.How to get Salt from the Ocean (Round 2):That took awhile, but now we got the salt. Now back to the leather.How to make Leather From a Deer (Round 4):Lime? As in the fruit? Oh… you mean limestone. We can find some of that.How to make Lime:How to make Leather From a Deer (Round 4, continued):6. Boil the brain of the deer in water to create a tanning solution.Oh darn. Now we need a pot. And a fire.How to make a Fire:Ok great, we have a fire. Now we need a pot.How to make a Clay Pot:Great. We’re on a roll now. Back to that leather.How to make Leather From a Deer (Round 4, continued):6. Boil the brain of the deer in water to create a tanning solution.7. Soak the deer hide in the tanning solution.8. Hang the leather up to dry.Whew. Finally. Leather.How to make a Leather Cord (Round 2):How to make a Stone Pickaxe (Round 2):Alright. Got it.How to make an Steel Pickaxe (Round 2):A Forge? You mean we can’t use a regular fire? Ahh. Its not hot enough.How to build a Forge:Charcoal?How to make Charcoal:????…As you can see. Even the simplest tasks are not so simple. It seems like technology is progressing really fast today, but that is because of all the technology that literally took ages to figure out.How long would it take to figure out how to do any of the simple technologies above, simply by trial and error? It could take a really long time, for example, to figure out what Iron Ore looks like, and how to build a forge hot enough to melt it. Especially if you didn’t even have any idea that Iron even exists.I mean, come on. Everyone knows rocks don’t melt. If they did, how could we use them to build ovens. Right????So there are a lot of hurdles. But once a technology has been figured out, we can build on it to create the next step.These days, we’ve figured out enough things to do a lot. We’ve also figured out something called science, which is the art of figuring out new things.Tasks that were once really hard, become much easier. Look at how you would get that pickaxe in the 21st Century.How to get a Steel Pickaxe (Modern Edition)Ahh. Technology.

Answer: Very, very difficult. Extremely improbable.The human beamed back in that time will not know anything about the fauna and flora back then. Will not know which plants are edible. Flowering plants weren’t even present back then, so forget any and all angiosperms. No wheat, rice, beans, acorns, maple seeds, apples, oranges, bananas … orThe geography and even the geology would be very different to what we are used to. Climactic patterns would be very different. Since most of the landmass was coalesced into a single supercontinent, seasons far inVery, very difficult. Extremely improbable.The human beamed back in that time will not know anything about the fauna and flora back then. Will not know which plants are edible. Flowering plants weren’t even present back then, so forget any and all angiosperms. No wheat, rice, beans, acorns, maple seeds, apples, oranges, bananas … orThe geography and even the geology would be very different to what we are used to. Climactic patterns would be very different. Since most of the landmass was coalesced into a single supercontinent, seasons far inland were quite extreme.Nothing resembling modern maps.Then there is the issue of animals. The dinosaurs were already well into dominating the dry land, but land-living crocodiles were common, too. The person wouldn’t know which animal was safe to hunt and which one would fight back, or even make a meal of the hunter.Well … damn it!The issue of pathogens makes it all the worse. Our immunity is not suited for fighting against prehistoric pathogens. A single cut or bruise could prove fatal. And then there were pathogen-carrying pests such as ancient mosquitoes, flies etc.You wouldn’t want to sleep around these sort of critters!

Answer: I will give two answers: the first on more solid historical ground, and the second more speculative.First answer: Civilization had to wait for the end of the ice age, which terminated about 15,000 years ago. At that time the glaciers had piled up a lot of good topsoil at its edge, and the melting ice provided plenty of water. Agriculture was developed for the first time in human existence, at first in Turkey. Agriculture is key; it means that not everyone has to hunt and gather, but food can be farmed by specialists. That allows others to becomes tradesmen, businessmen, and physics professors.Continue ReadingI will give two answers: the first on more solid historical ground, and the second more speculative.First answer: Civilization had to wait for the end of the ice age, which terminated about 15,000 years ago. At that time the glaciers had piled up a lot of good topsoil at its edge, and the melting ice provided plenty of water. Agriculture was developed for the first time in human existence, at first in Turkey. Agriculture is key; it means that not everyone has to hunt and gather, but food can be farmed by specialists. That allows others to becomes tradesmen, businessmen, and physics professors.Do not underestimate the rapidity of technical innovation during this period. It may seem slow, but that’s because today we take bronze and iron for granted. There were likely enormous advances in farming technology, but the wooden tools and plows used did not last for archeologists to study.The question says that “advanced technology” took place 500 years ago. With the rapid growth of technology, it mightSecond answer (much more speculative, perhaps even whimsical): The true advance of humans came from a human genetic mutation that took place about 3000 years ago. One of my names for it is “the dissatisfaction gene.” This was a gene that made people unsatisfied with their present situation. Animals never developed this; they search for environments that are good enough, and then they are satisfied. House cats are prototypical. But even elephants seem to be happy when they find a place with lots of grass and water.Not humans. Those who had this gene were never happy enough with what they had, and they pushed and developed and worked hard and created an ever expanding civilization.If you too are cursed with this gene (I think I am) then it is difficult to be happy, because no matter what you achieve, you want to do more. For that reason I sometimes refer to it as the “Original Sin Gene.” Like the original sin of Judaism and Christianity, it dooms humans to suffering. No matter how much life improves, we want it to be better.There is a solution that I personally try. I recognize that I must continue to strive to achieve more, and this is my burden. But I also can rise above it, and look at the world, and realize how blessed I am to live in such a wonderful place. Enjoy what we have, but never stop working to make it even better.
name: Naomi Green
question: https://www.quora.com/Did-anyone-think-if-its-something-suspicious-how-humans-advanced-technologically-more-in-the-last-150-years-than-compared-to-the-millions-of-years-of-human-life

Answer: Not suspicious at all. Humans simply adapted over time developing from small isolated groups into larger groups. The size of the groups allowed some degree of survival partitioning into efficiencies. Once basic needs were met by efficient processes, other developments became possible. A single person can barely survive in nature, but groups make the probability of survival increase. The saved time allowed development of various inventions which beget more invention and understanding.

Answer: University rankings use a limited set of assessment criteria such as international students and faculty, research citations, peer assessment. Israel's universities may not rank high on international metrics due to local enrollment. They may also choose to publish less in favour of commercial exploitation of their ideas. Ie, they create more patents instead of academic papers. But academic rankings don't normally track patents or entrepreneurial activities.In ARWU ranking, Israel is reasonably well reflected.World University Rankings - 2016

In order to fulfill their charge, they are mysteriously blessed with tremendous power and control over the positive matter universes. They are also gifted with unparalleled intellects. Though not infallible, the Monitors have triumphantly served as the Multiverse’s first line of defense against contamination, corruption, for an imperceivThe Monitors.The Monitors are responsible for examining the progression and development of each universe as well as protecting it from crisis. In order to fulfill their charge, they are mysteriously blessed with tremendous power and control over the positive matter universes. They are also gifted with unparalleled intellects. Though not infallible, the Monitors have triumphantly served as the Multiverse’s first line of defense against contamination, corruption, for an imperceivably long period of time.Monitor spacecrafts alone are fueled by baby universes they’ve managed to contain within their nanotech. These spacecrafts, while microscopic to them, are actually quite vast in size to those within the Orrery of Worlds in which each universe resides. Their spacecraft/s designed for offensive purposes are capable of wiping clean entire universes, effectively sanitizing them after contamination.Monitors have been able to drill from the Monitor Sphere, past the Sphere of the Gods, and into the Orrery in four quadrants. In laymen’s terms, they have proven themselves able to drill past countless realms of the Multiverse. This is all in order to accumulate Bleed, or as they refer to it, Ultramenstruum. They are self-claimed to be the only ones who can properly handle this awesome stuff (though Superman has successfully contained it.)Monitors time and time again have also successfully designed and initiated entire universes. Monitor Nix Uotan has managed to rebuild Earth-51 based upon the former which was destroyed during crisis. Meanwhile, Monitor ideominers have managed to retrieve “threads’ of ideas and sew them together to form an artificial universe they call “pseudo-verse”: Earth-35.We can quite seriously argue for several dozen minutes to hours on endI don’t know about you all, but I’m not about to argue with anyone on such a matter; it sounds just plain exhausting and futile. Answer: Full disclosure: I’m a Marvel guy because that’s what I grew up reading. However, I read DC comics, too.However, even if Marvel copied DC characters, which is only partially true, Marvel had some innovations.1). Peter Parker wasn’t your typical hero. He was scrawny and unpopular and had real strengths and flaws.2). The books were set in the real world which gave them a gravitas that DC heroes lacked.3) The books were used as allegories for real world problems like racism and the red scare.So, while I personally prefer Marvel, both Marvel and DC have their differences and advantages, dependingFull disclosure: I’m a Marvel guy because that’s what I grew up reading. However, I read DC comics, too.However, even if Marvel copied DC characters, which is only partially true, Marvel had some innovations.1). Peter Parker wasn’t your typical hero. He was scrawny and unpopular and had real strengths and flaws.2). The books were set in the real world which gave them a gravitas that DC heroes lacked.3) The books were used as allegories for real world problems like racism and the red scare.So, while I personally prefer Marvel, both Marvel and DC have their differences and advantages, depending on your personal taste.However, just because characters may seem similar on the surface (similar powers, origins, etc) there is actual a lot of nuance that creates some marked differences.

Answer: Uhh… we’ve made a lot of them.In fact, if you’ve seen it in a TV show or film and the costume didn’t need CG or post work in a studio, then human beings used real life fabrics, plastics, rubber, and whatever else they needed to bring that super hero’s outfit to life.So, technically, if the superhero’s outfit is basically just a costume that covers their skin with purpose to disguise them, then we’ve made countless examples that work in real life.However, If the suit in the comics is supposed to be clothes AND say, body armor, like Iron Man’s armor……well, we’re still working on that. What fictiUhh… we’ve made a lot of them.In fact, if you’ve seen it in a TV show or film and the costume didn’t need CG or post work in a studio, then human beings used real life fabrics, plastics, rubber, and whatever else they needed to bring that super hero’s outfit to life.So, technically, if the superhero’s outfit is basically just a costume that covers their skin with purpose to disguise them, then we’ve made countless examples that work in real life.However, If the suit in the comics is supposed to be clothes AND say, body armor, like Iron Man’s armor……well, we’re still working on that. What fiction can do isn’t always realistically possible… we’re still a long way from a function Mk. 3 Iron Man suit. But as far as practical costumes that could be worn by a super hero? Sure… we have the technology for that.All though I would definitely avoid these outfits:They were almost pure leather and couldn’t really bend at the joints very well. You can check out the DVD outtakes for some hilarious moments brought about by costume difficulty.And for that matter, avoid this:A bat suit made almost entirely out of black rubber, which was heavy, unbreathable, and was very difficult to move in… especially the head and neck. (Looked great though!) I personally think of this outfit as a necessary evil; Batman’s costume is supposed to be black in the comics, but due to coloring limitations, it usually is drawn blue. This costume really blew me away as a kid, and set a new tone for how Batman could be done in live action.But when it comes to functionality, I actually have to give a lot of credit for this outfit:It’s cheesy looking, but it breathes, it moves, and it’s a spot-on match for what Superman wore in the comics at the time. I still look at this and think, “Damn, that’s Superman!” It’s definitely showing it’s age in this photograph, but Christopher Reeve and that outfit certainly made an impression on me as a kid.40 years later, costume making has improved greatly. I love all the work that’s put into modern costuming, and have friends here in Los Angeles who are professional designers, as well as other friends who are serious cosplayers… it’s AMAZING what can be done now.

Answer: Hmmmmm this could be interesting…There’s plenty of options for this across all of comic history. But one of my personal favorites I can think of….Iron ManEasily one of my favorites, because it shows what Tony is capable of if he ever felt the need to let loose with his intelligence.Say what you want about Death Battle, they nailed it with the moments starting at 19:30. (And yes, it is this line animated):“I’m the most intelligent, capable person on the planet. I’m notTony Stark can be very egotistic, but weHmmmmm this could be interesting…There’s plenty of options for this across all of comic history. But one of my personal favorites I can think of….Iron ManEasily one of my favorites, because it shows what Tony is capable of if he ever felt the need to let loose with his intelligence.Say what you want about Death Battle, they nailed it with the moments starting at 19:30. (And yes, it is this line animated):“I’m the most intelligent, capable person on the planet. I’m notTony Stark can be very egotistic, but we can all agree there’s a reason he is in the top five smartest Marvel characters in comics.This little strip might be one of my favorite proof of it. The armor Tony is wearing is the Endosym armor, a combo of liquid smart metal and symbiote, capable of facing down the likes of Havoc and Storm with ease. Even his Hulkbuster Mark II that fought Green Scar Hulk was no match for it.Top that off that he had just given Matt Murdock, aka Daredevil, his sight back using the Extremis virus and had tricked the entirety of San Fransisco into thinking of him as the greatest person in the world (despite his lack of morals from the Inversion) and you realize that this Tony may not be the smartest version of himself (he’s had a lot of smart moments over the years), but this is him if he weren’t limited by his own morals and codes. Loose as they might be, we should still be thankful Stark has those morals, or the Marvel Earth might be a much different place.Cheers!

Answer: In which department?In modern comics, it’s already been done by ImageYeah they technically don’t make as much money as Marvel or DC, but in my opinion they’re more consistent with their comics and don’t have any of the problems DC and Marvel doMarvel keeps making trash ass comic book events rapidly and DC makes keeping up with their universe near impossible with the constant retcons and reboots. Image doesn’t have those problems, plain and simpleMovies? The video game genre is my best guessI’m going to be honest, while I remain unconvinced that the majority of people are getting tired of superIn which department?In modern comics, it’s already been done by ImageYeah they technically don’t make as much money as Marvel or DC, but in my opinion they’re more consistent with their comics and don’t have any of the problems DC and Marvel doMarvel keeps making trash ass comic book events rapidly and DC makes keeping up with their universe near impossible with the constant retcons and reboots. Image doesn’t have those problems, plain and simpleMovies? The video game genre is my best guessI’m going to be honest, while I remain unconvinced that the majority of people are getting tired of superhero movies, if I’m wrong then the Video Game genre would be my prediction of being the next most popular thing in blockbuster moviesThey’re similar in that they have lots of source material to work with, but video games have barely scratched the surface with theirs and lately we’ve been getting some damn good VG moviesSonic The Hedgehog 1&2, Detective Pikachu, there’s an upcoming Mario movie that’ll be… interesting, I’m interested in what other video game movies will be like in the futureIf not video game movies, then I’m honestly not sure. My best second guess would be the MonsterVerse, but they barely produce these days. Both a blessing and a curse than it’s not as popular as DC and Marvel, but I’m still invested in it regardlessIn video games? Already doneI’m not an expert on the video game community, but from what I know I’m pretty sure Nintendo is the MCU of video gamesThey’ve got plenty of awesome game series. Kirby and Pokémon alone is honestly better than DC and Marvel combined in video games, let alone throwing Mario and Legend of Zelda into the mix. Smash Ultimate is my current favorite video game of all time and is pretty much the definitive fighting game in most peoples eyes, which is why Minecraft characters were collabed in it and I wish PS4 Spider-Man would make his debutNintendo regularly produces way more video games than Marvel and DC combined and they’re usually pretty good. Yeah there are some stinkers here and there, namely Brilliant Diamond and Shining Pearl, but there are also awesome games like Legends Arceus and Kirby The Forgotten LandNeither are trash in video games, but it’s pretty obvious who’s king around hereEtc, Marvel and DC are two of the greatest entertainment companies out there but there are plenty of areas they are beat. Modern Comics, Video Games,That’s my two cents

Answer: Marvel technology is far more advanced! And also more real.Take for example Tony Stark. He is what Batman should be in terms of intelligence. We know Tony Stark is a human with an incredible IQ. But his technology allows him to be a superhero, to do superhuman things. And his Iron Man suits makes it all more believable.With Bruce Wayne we got a human that wears a suit that can only stop little more than a bullet. His utility belt is severally limited. And in most cases what he pulls from his belt is clear plot convenience. While if he instead had a batsuit made with highly advanced nanotechnolMarvel technology is far more advanced! And also more real.Take for example Tony Stark. He is what Batman should be in terms of intelligence. We know Tony Stark is a human with an incredible IQ. But his technology allows him to be a superhero, to do superhuman things. And his Iron Man suits makes it all more believable.With Bruce Wayne we got a human that wears a suit that can only stop little more than a bullet. His utility belt is severally limited. And in most cases what he pulls from his belt is clear plot convenience. While if he instead had a batsuit made with highly advanced nanotechnology, then we at least could have a Batman that is actually believable.Not just Tony Stark. In Marvel be it the Fantastic Four, Peter Parker, Beast (X-Men), intelligence and intellectual achievements are much more appreciated and used in the actual fight of villains. While in DC we see more raw power but not that much intelligence.And that intelligence I find the stories to be more enjoyable and actually more realistic.
